description.narrative: Over the last decade, the Burundian government has taken numerous measures to limit civic space in the country, including the right to freedom of expression. Civil society has shrunken and many NGOs were suspended. Over 200 000 Burundians have sought refuge in neighbouring countries. Against the backdrop of these events, the SCC programme in Burundi focusses on countering the repression of human rights defenders by the Burundian government. In parallel, the aim is to put pressure on the government to end human rights violations and to ensure accountable to the perpetrators. In particular, the programme targets women human rights defenders, who seem to be especially subject to human rights violations.

The activity is part of a larger programme implemented by the Strengthening Civil Courage Alliance, consisting of ABAAD – Resource Center for Gender Equality, Amnesty International The Netherlands, DefendDefenders, PAX and their partner networks.

The main objective is for Burundian CSOs and human rights defenders to have a safer space and increased capacity to address the human rights situation and to become a healthy countervailing power in their own society. More specifically, the programme pursues for the Burundian authorities to respond to calls for adherence to international and regional human rights standards and the protection of human rights defenders. Secondly, it aims that by the end of the programme, the Burundian authorities respond to calls for adherence to human rights standards and for the accountability for grave human rights violations.

The main target groups are the Burundian human rights defenders and civil society organisations whose leadership is in exile, and human rights monitors in Burundi (they gather information for human rights CSOs). Another important target group are victims and families of victims that have experience grave human rights violations.
